channel.title: Comments on: Sao Paulo, Brazil: The City Without Advertising
channel.description: Amit Schreiber's Blog | הבלוג של עמית שרייבר

item.title: By: Amit
item.dc:creator: Amit
item.description:
rom: Thanks a lot. Looks like a good read. I'll keep the book name in mind for my next book purchase. Maybe I learn Russian right after I master perl (read: probably never) :)
Ariel: I had to look up the reference for "Algie can fly" :). About that article link: I drive by that sign quite a lot. I think it's kind of funny, actually.
item.content:encoded:
rom: Thanks a lot. Looks like a good read. I’ll keep the book name in mind for my next book purchase. Maybe I learn Russian right after I master perl (read: probably never) :)

Ariel: I had to look up the reference for “Algie can fly” :). About that article link: I drive by that sign quite a lot. I think it’s kind of funny, actually.

item.title: By: Ariel Cohen
item.dc:creator: Ariel Cohen
item.description: I don't know about municipal corruption but Algie can sure fly!
item.content:encoded: I don’t know about municipal corruption but Algie can sure fly!

item.title: By: rom
item.dc:creator: rom
item.description: There's a story about such a future where all advertising is banned. It's not as bright as it may seem to be. The story is 'The Girl Who Was Plugged In' by http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Tiptree,_Jr . If by any chance you read russian, i'll be happy to supply you a link ;)
item.content:encoded: There’s a story about such a future where all advertising is banned. It’s not as bright as it may seem to be. The story is ‘The Girl Who Was Plugged In’ by http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Tiptree,_Jr . If by any chance you read russian, i’ll be happy to supply you a link ;)
